Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:

What it is: Slack somewhat recently announced their emoji response system, a great way to cut down on superfluous messages. When you respond to a message with just an emoji, slackbot tells you about the new feature.

Why it’s good: Telling users about new features can be difficult. Release notes aren’t very interesting, so most of the time people don’t pay a lot of attention to them.

Instead of beating you over the head with the idea, (or expecting you to find it in the release notes) slackbot gives you a quick message that tells you how to use the feature. It only shows up for the first few times you use it (I had to go find an old, unused Slack because it wouldn’t come up in any of the ones I use on a regular basis) and it only shows up when you respond with just an emoji. The subtle details matter here too, slackbot indicates that the message is only visible to the user through a color shift and short disclaimer.

What it is: Envato is a company all about creative community commerce on the web. That’s not what we’re going to be talking about here though, their website is so insanely fast that it’s worth talking about.

Why it’s good: The first time I clicked a link on this site, I honestly thought something went wrong. The entire page changed so quickly, could it have possibly loaded a new page that fast? I included a clock on this gif so that you could see how quickly this thing loads. I was in an incognito window too, so this is without caching.

I’ve become so used to websites loading slowly (even over broadband) that a multimedia site loading in under a second shocked me. Performance is such an integral part of experience, but we expect it to be a piece that’s layered on at the end—a task that the engineers check off right before launch. Keeping performance on the table as a constant consideration is vital to building products that can deliver on user expectations for speed.

What it is: The mindmapping tool XMind creates its data set in such a way that you can copy and paste data between it and a spreadsheet, like excel.

Why it is good: I know I’m running the risk of sounding like I’m just trying to sell this product, but hear me out. For about 2 years, I tried to find something that would just create a flow diagram from an excel file. I even tried building it on my own in Axure at one point. (with hilariously limited success)

Everything that I found was incredibly rigid. There were some things that showed promise, like yED or LucidChart, but in each case, I had to format my excel file in some arcane fashion. I did it in LucidChart at one point for a large navigation, and it took me about 3 hours. It sucked.

When I discovered that this product just let me work with my data in my own mental model, I was so excited I almost cried. I danced around for an entire afternoon. I copied it back and forth repeatedly just to watch it happen. Allow me to remind you, this is for a program that draws a chart.

When I read posts like this one “Delightful Interaction Design Needs to Die”, I’m reluctantly in agreement. True delight doesn’t come from a widget animating unexpectedly, that only provokes surprise. Delight comes from a something fitting into my needs, snapping into my mental model, and extending my ability to pursue my goals.

What it is: Google Fi is Google’s phone carrier. It’s a combination of leased traffic from Sprint and T-Mobile, and a lot of verified Wi Fi networks. The explainations on their website use simple language and animations to help convey the fairly complex techologies that make it work.

Why it’s good: This is a master class in explaining complex, technological concepts to inexperienced users. How do you go about explaining wifi switching? Multi network use? VPN tunneling? This site brushes all of these concepts, and explains them in a way that either lays out the concept clearly, or explains it generally to the point that the user needs to understand.

Take for instance the section on data encryption. They know that most people have heard to be careful of sending data over unencrypted networks, so is auto wifi connecting safe? Here’s how they explain it: “Your data is secured through encryption when we connect you to open Wi-Fi hotspots. It’s like your data has a private tunnel to drive through.” Two sentences, a lot left unsaid, but enough that I understand why it’s not a concern.

What it is: Most of the cards you get in Hearthstone come in these packs of 5. You can purchase them directly, or get them as rewards.

Why it’s good: Whenever you are creating a system based off of microtransactions, there’s always the question of “What is the user buying?” Whenever I’ve played a game that requires me to pay just to play it, I respond colorfully and delete it. (I’m looking at you Clash of Clans)

Hearthstone is a card game, so how do you make a digital card that has worth? By wrapping the card acquisition in a little fanfare, Hearthstone adds a level of anticipation and reverence to each pack. Not only that, the pack bursting apart and each card flipping as you click it reinforces Hearthstone’s physical interface.

The blue aura that you see around the last card I open indicates it’s of higher rarity, and the game’s narrator (The Innkeeper) exclaims “Rare!” when I reveal it. It does this with any card that isn’t a common card, so it is guaranteed once a pack. The anticipation is small, but as an avid player of the game, my heart rate skyrockets when I hover on a card with an orange glow. (Which is the rarest type, legendary) It’s one of those hooks that doesn’t lose its magic when you see behind the curtain.

If you want more information on Hearthstone’s physical interface (Inculuding the pack opening), I highly recommend this amazing presentation by one of its designers, Derek Sakamoto.
